title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #642: Cycles with More Vertices than Diagonals**

Let f(n) be the maximal edges in a graph where every cycle has more vertices than diagonals. Is f(n) ≪ n?

**Status**: OPEN

**Known Bounds**: Ω(n^(3/2)) ≤ f(n) ≤ O(n(log n)^8)

title: Cycle Structure
content:
**Cycle G**: A structure with:
- vertices: List V (the cycle vertices)
- length_ge_3: at least 3 vertices
- is_cycle: consecutive vertices are adjacent
- no_repeated: no repeated vertices

This captures cycles in the graph-theoretic sense.

title: Cycle Length
content:
**Cycle.len C**: The number of vertices in cycle C.

This is the key quantity compared against diagonals.

title: Cycle Adjacency
content:
**CycleAdjacent n i j**: Two positions i, j in a cycle of length n are adjacent if they differ by 1 (mod n).

Used to determine which edges are NOT diagonals.

title: Diagonal Definition
content:
**IsDiagonal C e**: Edge e is a diagonal of cycle C if:
- It connects two distinct cycle vertices
- Those vertices are NOT adjacent on the cycle
- The edge exists in the graph

Diagonals are 'chords' cutting across the cycle.

title: Diagonal Count
content:
**diagonalCount C**: Number of diagonals present in cycle C.

Counts edges that cut across the cycle (not on the cycle itself).

title: Cycle-Diagonal Condition
content:
**SatisfiesCycleDiagonalCondition G**: For every cycle C in G:

|V(C)| > diagonalCount(C)

Every cycle has more vertices than diagonals.

title: Extremal Function f(n)
content:
**f(n)**: Maximum edges in an n-vertex graph satisfying the cycle-diagonal condition.

This is the central quantity of the problem.

title: Tree Lower Bound
content:
**f_ge_tree**: f(n) ≥ n - 1.

Trees have no cycles, so trivially satisfy the condition.

They have n - 1 edges.

title: Complete Graph Bound
content:
**f_le_complete**: f(n) ≤ n(n-1)/2.

No graph has more edges than the complete graph.

title: Maximum Diagonals
content:
**max_diagonals_in_cycle**: A cycle of length k has at most k(k-3)/2 possible diagonals.

Total pairs - cycle edges = C(k,2) - k.

title: Chen-Erdős-Staton (1996)
content:
**chen_erdos_staton**: f(n) ≤ 2n^(3/2).

The first non-trivial upper bound on the extremal function.

Proved in 1996 by Chen, Erdős, and Staton.

title: DMMS Bound (2024)
content:
**dmms_2024**: f(n) ≤ n(log n)^8.

Draganić-Methuku-Munhá Correia-Sudakov improved the CES bound significantly.

Uses expander graph techniques.

title: DMMS Improves CES
content:
**dmms_improves_ces**: For n ≥ 1000, the DMMS bound beats CES.

n(log n)^8 < 2n^(3/2) for large n.

The improvement factor is n^(1/2) / (log n)^8.

title: Hamburger-Szegedy Conjecture
content:
**HamburgerSzegedyConjecture**: f(n) = o(n).

∀ ε > 0, ∃ N, ∀ n ≥ N: f(n) < εn

The main open question of Problem #642.

title: Linear Bound Conjecture
content:
**LinearBoundConjecture**: ∃ C > 0, f(n) ≤ Cn.

A weaker version: f(n) = O(n).

Still open!

title: Girth Definition
content:
**HasGirth G g**: Graph G has girth ≥ g.

No cycles of length < g exist in G.

Girth-5 means no triangles (C₃) or 4-cycles (C₄).

title: Girth-5 Satisfies
content:
**girth_5_satisfies**: Girth ≥ 5 graphs satisfy the condition.

With girth ≥ 5, every cycle has length ≥ 5, and a cycle of length k ≥ 5 can have at most (k-3) diagonals before violating k > diagonals.

Actually, girth ≥ 5 graphs have NO short cycles, so the condition is trivially satisfied since there are no diagonals on cycles of length ≥ 5 that could accumulate.

title: Turán C₄-free
content:
**turan_C4_free**: Girth-5 graphs can have Ω(n^(3/2)) edges.

Constructions from finite geometry (incidence graphs of projective planes).

This gives the lower bound on f(n).

title: Lower Bound
content:
**f_lower_bound**: f(n) ≥ Ω(n^(3/2)).

From girth-5 graph constructions.

There's a significant gap to the upper bound!

title: Expander Graphs
content:
**IsExpander G d λ**: G is a (n, d, λ)-expander.

- All vertices have degree d (d-regular)
- Second eigenvalue ≤ λ (spectral gap)

Expanders have strong mixing properties.

title: Sublinear Expanders
content:
**IsSublinearExpander G**: Degree d = n^ε for some ε < 1.

These are 'sparse' expanders.

Key tool in the DMMS proof.

title: Expander Cycle Lemma
content:
**expander_cycle_lemma**: Random walks in good expanders find cycles with many diagonals.

Key lemma: Either G violates the condition OR G has few edges.

This is the heart of the DMMS improvement.

title: Short Cycles OK
content:
**short_cycles_ok**: Cycles of length ≤ 4 always satisfy the condition.

For k ≤ 4: k > k(k-3)/2
- k=3: 3 > 0 ✓
- k=4: 4 > 2 ✓

title: Pentagon Violation
content:
**pentagon_all_diags_violates**: A pentagon (5-cycle) with all diagonals violates the condition.

5 vertices, 5 diagonals → 5 > 5 is FALSE.

Critical transition point!

title: Critical Length
content:
**critical_length**: For k ≥ 5, k ≤ k(k-3)/2.

Long cycles CAN have more diagonals than vertices.

The transition happens at length 5.

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_642_bounds**: Summary of known bounds.

Ω(n^(3/2)) ≤ f(n) ≤ O(n(log n)^8)

The question f(n) = o(n) remains OPEN.

title: Problem Status
content:
**erdos_642_answer**: OPEN problem.

**erdos_642_status**: Hamburger-Szegedy conjecture unresolved.

Significant gap remains between known bounds.

title: Bounds Gap
content:
**bounds_gap**: The gap between bounds is (log n)^8 / n^(1/2).

Upper / Lower = n(log n)^8 / n^(3/2) = (log n)^8 / √n

This gap shrinks slowly (only polylog / polynomial).
